latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 164, Number 6 (Wednesday, January 10, 2018)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mrs. DEMINGS:H.R. 4762.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8[Page H132]

latestAction.text: ASSUMING FIRST SPONSORSHIP - Mr. Garrett asked unanimous consent that he may hereafter be considered as the first sponsor of H.R. 756, a bill originally introduced by former Representative Chaffetz, for purposes of adding cosponsors and requesting reprintings pursuant to clause 7 of rule XII. Agreed to without objection.

item.latestTitle: A bill to require the United States Postal Service to designate a single, unique ZIP code for particular communities.

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs.

bill.title: To require the United States Postal Service to designate a single, unique ZIP code for particular communities.

item.title: To require the United States Postal Service to designate a single, unique ZIP code for particular communities.
To require the United States Postal Service to designate a single, unique ZIP code for particular communities.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

item.name: Introduced in House
item.text: This bill requires the U. S. Postal Service to designate a single, unique ZIP code for each of the communities of Ocoee and Oakland, Florida.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
